title: US government's annual budget deficit largest since 2012
text:
Washington | The US government ended fiscal year 2019 with the largest budget deficit in seven years as gains in tax receipts were offset by higher spending and growing debt service payments, the Treasury department said.

The figures reflect the second full budget year under US President Donald Trump, a Republican, and come at a time when the country has an expanding tax base with strong economic growth and an unemployment rate currently near a 50-year low.

Earlier this year the US Congress passed a two-year budget deal backed by Trump that would increase federal spending on defence and other domestic programs. AP

The US budget deficit widened to $US984 billion ($1.4 trillion), which was 4.6 per cent of the nation's gross domestic product. The previous fiscal year deficit was $US779 billion, with a deficit-to-GDP-ratio of 3.8 per cent. Total receipts increased by 4 per cent but outlays rose by 8.2 per cent.

The deficit reached a peak of $US1.4 trillion in 2009 as the Obama administration and Congress took emergency measures to shore up the nation's banking system during the global financial crisis and provide stimulus to an economy in recession.

The annual budget deficit had been reduced to $US585 billion by the end of former President Barack Obama's second term in 2016 and Republicans in Congress during that time criticised Obama, a Democrat, for not reducing it further.
description: The US budget deficit for the latest fiscal year widened to $US984 billion, which was 4.6 per cent of the nation's gross domestic product.
